channel.title: Objectweb ASM
channel.description: Is it possible to make same things with ASM which are made with BCEL ?

item.title: Objectweb ASM
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“sh!ft, post:13, topic:155358”]And really, if you must have speed, then you may as well write an updater in C++ using something like utf8-cpp and the defined java variables found in the JNI documentation. A processor interpreted assembly language is always faster than a ‘virtualized’ machine any day.[/quote]you dont need utf8 support unless you wanted to write a general bytecode library, as opposed to specifically tooled for runescape.

[quote=“qauters, post:18, topic:155358”]Isn’t that the same when comparing BCEL to ASM :). BCEL is what most people use, but it’s kinda slow. ASM is what a few people use, but it’s quick. C++ is what the diehards use, but there aren’t any of them on this forum :P. Also when you create a fully functional bytecode libary in c++, you could have created a packet bot aswell.[/quote]if anyone had an ounce of common sense, they wouldnt be comparing times, but comparing methodologies instead

Read full topic

item.title: Objectweb ASM
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:14, topic:155358”][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=212083.msg1856273#msg1856273 date=1193767813]
Its*

Yeah BCEL has a few kinks and bugs, but none as threatening as ASM’s visitor complex… The visitor complex does incur speed naturally, but it also invokes a distaste that most coders can’t get their heads around.

And really, if you must have speed, then you may as well write an updater in C++ using something like utf8-cpp and the defined java variables found in the JNI documentation. A processor interpreted assembly language is always faster than a ‘virtualized’ machine any day.
[/quote]

OMG it took 500ms in C++ against 2000ms with ASM.

Looks like another ePenis fight.

The least you can do is keep it in Java.[/quote]
Isn’t that the same when comparing BCEL to ASM :). BCEL is what most people use, but it’s kinda slow. ASM is what a few people use, but it’s quick. C++ is what the diehards use, but there aren’t any of them on this forum :P. Also when you create a fully functional bytecode libary in c++, you could have created a packet bot aswell.

Read full topic

Incidentally, your correction was wrong. Its is possessive. It’s is the contraction of It + is.[/quote]
My mistake.

And really, if you must have speed, then you may as well write an updater in C++ using something like utf8-cpp and the defined java variables found in the JNI documentation. A processor interpreted assembly language is always faster than a ‘virtualized’ machine any day.[/quote]

item.title: Objectweb ASM
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:11, topic:155358”]I agree. You can do well with either tool. ASM is a bit more refined. BCEL reminds me more of what a reverse-engineer-oriented approach would produce. ASM looks like it was designed by developers that actually understand what patterns and anti-patterns are with regards to software development. BCEL seems to have been designed off-the-cuff. In all honesty, I’ve only ever used BCEL. I tried using ASM once, but I felt gimped and didn’t have the patience that BAsh seemed to have demonstrated. I was certain that a pattern matching equivalent existed in ASM and I wanted to want to use ASM but in trying to convert my project(s) to ASM I simply got frustrated and dropped the idea figuring that it was taking up too much of my time. Instead I grabbed the BCEL 5.1 source and made massive changes. I cut the load time in half but it still doesn’t compare to the speed of ASM. On the flipside, I don’t think that I have the time to implement the tools I have made specifically for this game in ASM.

It’s six in one, half dozen in the other. Vim vs Emacs. IDEA vs Eclipse. Each has it’s strengths and weaknesses.[/quote]
Its*

Yeah BCEL has a few kinks and bugs, but none as threatening as ASM’s visitor complex… The visitor complex does incur speed naturally, but it also invokes a distaste that most coders can’t get their heads around.

And really, if you must have speed, then you may as well write an updater in C++ using something like utf8-cpp and the defined java variables found in the JNI documentation. A processor interpreted assembly language is always faster than a ‘virtualized’ machine any day.

Read full topic

item.title: Objectweb ASM
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I agree. You can do well with either tool. ASM is a bit more refined. BCEL reminds me more of what a reverse-engineer-oriented approach would produce. ASM looks like it was designed by developers that actually understand what patterns and anti-patterns are with regards to software development. BCEL seems to have been designed off-the-cuff. In all honesty, I’ve only ever used BCEL. I tried using ASM once, but I felt gimped and didn’t have the patience that BAsh seemed to have demonstrated. I was certain that a pattern matching equivalent existed in ASM and I wanted to want to use ASM but in trying to convert my project(s) to ASM I simply got frustrated and dropped the idea figuring that it was taking up too much of my time. Instead I grabbed the BCEL 5.1 source and made massive changes. I cut the load time in half but it still doesn’t compare to the speed of ASM. On the flipside, I don’t think that I have the time to implement the tools I have made specifically for this game in ASM.

It’s six in one, half dozen in the other. Vim vs Emacs. IDEA vs Eclipse. Each has it’s strengths and weaknesses.

Read full topic

item.title: Objectweb ASM
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

I find ASM to be a lot clearer, you don’t have to know what a constant pool is because its all hidden. This means that if you load then dump classes using ASM you strip out redundant constants, foiling protection schemes that regex has a good example of. The disadvantage is that if you want to rename a class you have to loop through all the instructions but that is not such a big deal. It pays off when you don’t need to have a clue what the index is and if the constant exists in the first place.

ASM uses a visitor based method of reading classes. While this is fine if you were just doing simple operations that don’t involve any more context than the instruction/class declaration that you were reading, for more complex things you need to uses ClassNode. Here is some code that loads classes from a jar file into classnodes. It shouldn’t use a Vector since that class has been superseded by ArrayList but I’m lazy:

public static ClassNode[] loadClassesFromJar(File jarFile) throws Exception { Vector<ClassNode> cns = new Vector<ClassNode>(); ZipInputStream zipis = new ZipInputStream( new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(jarFile))); ZipEntry zipentry = null; while ((zipentry = zipis.getNextEntry()) != null) { String s = zipentry.getName(); if (!s.endsWith(".class")) continue; ClassReader cr = new ClassReader(zipis); ClassNode cn = new ClassNode(); cr.accept(cn, 0); cns.add(cn); } return cns.toArray(new ClassNode[0]); }
I find it easier as it hides all the crap in classfiles. All you really need to know is some basic knowledge on java and how a method descriptor is constructed: (Ljava/lang/String;)V

It also includes an analyzer which, although in its current form takes 20sec or so on my 2.4Ghz(single core) machine, proved invaluable with removing a whole bunch of crap. I have since shaved this down to 5sec or so by making SourceValue mutable but this is just an ePenis fight.

The only thing I found laking was no pattern matching using regular expressions. It was relatively easy to port the pattern matcher class and add increased functionality, see below.

I also found a few bugs in BCEL, for example one of the iterators does not return the last element of the instruction list, so I decided to use a tried and tested API that is actually updated. BCEL was last updated in 2001 or something like that. I find it annoying how you can have instructions that are targeted, resulting in exceptions and more code. ASM has label nodes, when you are pattern matching rather than having to deal with the obscure case that an instruction in your pattern has been targeted, you can simply not match that sequence of instructions.

Read full topic
